review:
The Mi Dual driver headphones delivers more than expected on one aspect - Bass. And there's bucket loads of it and that too without compromising too much on clarity.
This is my initial impression after using this headphone for almost 4 hours continuously. I will update this review with all other aspects and comparisons once I burn this in.

Edit : 9th March2020:
Before going into the review I own Mi in ear headphones pro, Vsonic GR02 Bass edition, Signature Acoustics Elements V2.1, Sennheisser HD598 SE, Realme Buds 2 and had Soundmagic E10. So I think I know a few things related to headphones when I compare them.
1. Design : Fairly standard design with a Y connector cable, 125 cm long braided cable which does not entangle and unfolds very easily. Kudos to that. I previously had Mi in ear headphones pro which entangled like anything. But from the splitter onward the cable is rubber and it does entangle a bit, but that potion is less luckily. The earbuds are made of anodised aluminium with rubber eartips. The ear buds does have magnets like realme earbuds and are relatively strong and helps to keep them stay together. No magnetic on off feature present.
2. Comfort : Nothing much to brag about here. It is comfortable like any other earphone and you'll be able to sleep on your side while wearing it.
3. Sound : BASS, BASS, BASS. That is what this is made for. It is dark and has tons of it.
Mids and high - the mids and high are somewhat overpowered by the bass which is bloated at times. But for the price it is OK. The male voice especially nasal tones seem a little upfront and unpleasant at times. For audiobooks and podcasts, it's easier to hear even in outdoors. The high or treble is where all the problems are. The treble is almost nonexistent. You'll need to adjust your equalizer a little bit to get the desired amount of treble to your liking.
Sound stage- affected by the bloated bass and less treble. The sound seems to be center staged and differentiating between instruments seems difficult.
4. Sound Isolation: Decent and comparable with others in the same price range.
5. Mic- It is of quite good quality with the person at the other end never experiencing any difficulties. The sound was very clear without much background noises and was clear. The mic is present in the right-side cable.
6. Value for money: this is a decent buy at a price of 799rs.

Final words: This headphone is made for the BASS-lovers. There is so much bass that it overpowers almost everything else. If you want a more round bodied sound you'll have to fiddle with the equaliser a little bit and once you does that you have got a decent pair of headphones with a very good mic. Even though a dual driver earphone, it doesn't live up to its name or its advertisements. Out of the box, it has nothing but bass. You'll get a much better sound in Sennheiser CX180, but it doesn't have a mic. For the price of 799, you have got a headphone which is better than the Boats Bassheads 225 and Realme buds 2. BUT, if you patiently wait and watch for lightning deals, you may find the Signature Acoustics Elements C12 version 2.1 @ 749 rs which is an absolute gem and trumps the Mi earphone on every aspect except for the muddy bass which is very clear in it. Also you get a foam tip with the signatures which in itself costs more than 200rs each pair.

So, the decision is all yours. For you, bass lovers, go ahead and buy it, you won't regret it. For pure sound lovers/audiophiles stay away.
Take your buying decision wisely.
Cheers!!!!

First of all I would like to request you all to first let the earphones to burn to its full so as to extract all its potential from these pair of earphones. At first when I bought these pair of earphones, I was not at all impressed with its performance. The bass seemed to be too high and the vocals and the highs seemed to be suppressed. But after continuous usage the sound quality improved greatly.
Previously I have used several other earphones like Sennheiser CX 213, Sennheiser HD 202 II, Sennheiser CX2.00G, Sony MDR EX110, Boats Bassheads 225, Realme Buds 2, etc. Among all of them I found the sound signature of Sennheiser to be the best. But the only complaint was the built quality as the wire quality of Sennheiser is not upto the mark. So after the Sennheiser CX 2.00G got damaged due to the wear and tear of its wires, I decided not to invest much money on earphones and searched for cheaper alternatives. So I bought Realme Buds 2 after a extensive research which cost me less than 5 times of my Sennheiser CX 2.00G. I just loved the sound quality of the Realme Buds 2 earphones. Since my sister urgently needed a pair of earphone I gifted her those after a brief period of use of less than a month.
While looking to buy a new pair of earphones since it is difficult for me to carry around the Sennheiser HD 202 II, I came across the Mi Dual Driver. The name itself caught my fancy and so I ordered it immediately by going through some YouTube reviews. But to my utter surprise these pair of earphones doesn't live up to its name and my expectations. Although they are dual driver they lacks the clarity in the vocals which one would expect from a dual driver earphone. The bass is too much for my liking as it overshadows the vocals and the treble. I myself use a Redmi K20 Pro smartphone and I tweaked the Equalizer of my phone and reduced the bass and tuned the highs to match it to my taste. But still I feel the vocals to be not crisp enough. From this perspective I would rather prefer the Realme Buds 2 over the Mi Dual Driver anyday due to its balanced sound signature.
One thing that Mi Dual Driver does better is retaining the minute details in the music and it also does a better job if you play a song at high volume as the sound doesn't get distorted which is bit of an issue with the Realme Buds 2.

Moreover, the call quality via the microphone of the Mi Dual Driver is very good but I would have preferred the inline remote to be flat though since it is quite difficult to detect the buttons as they are very slim.

At the end of this review I would recommend anyone looking for a pair of earphones providing balanced audio quality without compromising on the mids and the high at this price point to go for Realme Buds 2 or otherwise if they are bassheads than they can go for these without any second thought.

After using a pair of AKG earphones and realme buds 2, here are my overall product conclusions/comparisons.

Design (My rating 9/10)
These earphones have a good enough build quality and have a good ear fit. They don't look as good as the realme buds 2 but in the long run they should be more durable than those because of the 90 degree aux connector and thicker earphone wire casing.
The buds fit in very well and the extra tips are extremely useful. Overall these are comfortable enough to sleep in. The AKG's are the worst designed followed by these and the Realme Buds 2 come out on top of this category.

Sound (My rating 7/10)
These are pretty decent sounding in comparison to the other two wired earphones I've used but lean more towards the bass sound profile.
The mids and highs are a little faint in comparison but with the right use of equalizer tuning is fairly easy.
The Realme Buds 2 slightly sound better and the AKG's are the best in this category.

Durability (My rating 10/10)
My AKG's and Realme Buds 2 both had the same problem over the course of 2 years, the braided part was always fine but the joints near the connector and the earphones always used to wear badly. In terms of comparison I think these should do better because of the angled aux port and thicker wire casing.
This category is completely dominated by the Mi buds followed by the Realme Buds2 and then the AKG's

Pros:
1) build quality is decent, plastic body with lower part of the cables braided makes it feel stronger. Right angled pin is a good thing to have to avoid it coming in the way while using a device. 3 sized eartips in the package, to customise for fit, provided in a plastic pouch
2) sound quality is good and balanced. Music and lyrics sound even, one does not overpower the other, bass is not prominent. Good for listening to spoken audio and music.
3) call quality is good, based on my testing. People at the other end could hear me well, and so could I. Three button remote is great for adjusting call and music volume without having to reach for the phone (this does not work on iOS devices, but no issues with audio transmission and regular play/pause/ call answer) there are some extra features with long press for android devices mentioned in user manual in box.
4) The magnets on the earbuds is a good addition, useful to maage while wearing and good for small amount of cable management while not in use to avoid tangles
Cons:
1) the earphones come in a simple soft cardboard box, Mi earphones used to come in a hard plastic box earlier which was good for storage but not any longer, no carry pouch either. Storage is up to you, which may affect damage and longevity. Storing extra eartips also is an issue because of this. A carry pouch would be good
2) the pin on the sockets are dependable, in my past experience they last for about a year butbyiubhave to be careful with pulling on them since this is the weakest point of the earphones in my opinion.
3) the braiding on the cake is only on the lower part, after the divider into two sections for each ear it is soft rubber like plastic. This part is more susceptible to breaking, especially at the earbuds end where we ususally have the second most common point of failure.

I bought these as a replacement for my trusty Sennheiser CX-180. I switch between both of them depending on what I need them for. I'll list the pros and cons below.

Pros :
1: Treble and Low frequencies are absolutely perfect.
2: Sufficiently long cable, inline microphone.
3: Magnetic buds with convex and concave backs so you can tell which is right and left without needing to look.
4: Ear tips are soft, filtered design unlike other ear tips which are open mouth design.
5: Angled 3.5mm connector for ergonomics as well as durability.

Cons :
1: Mid range frequency isn't great.
2: Headphone cable is braided only halfway, tangles almost immediately where the braid ends.
3: Inline microphone and buttons are poorly designed. The cylinder shape that holds it is unnecessarily large, the buttons have no tactile difference between the three buttons so you'll definitely end up pressing pause instead of volume up/down.
4: The plastic housing of each bud isn't comfortable in ear. Within a matter of minutes you can feel the plastic pressing in your ear. I've changed tips as well as used third party tips, so no change.
5: To make place for the dual drivers the housing is large so also is cause for considerable weight and poor comfort.

Use this if you need it for very short travels that have a lot of outside noise. Good for gaming too due to the inline microphone.

Overall I still prefer my CX-180 for comfort and sound quality even though it doesn't have mic. Also Sennheiser warranty is 2 Years vs 6 Months for these.
